abstract.para: &app; is a graphical debugger for the GNOME desktop environment.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is an ongoing effort to write a standalone graphical debugger that integrates well in the GNOME desktop environment. It currently features a backend which uses the well known GNU Debugger gdb to debug C / C++ programs.

sect2.title: Perspectives
sect2.para: &app; is built with a plugin system that can offer several different perspectives. Currently the only perspective provided is a debugging perspective, but in the future, there may be perspectives added for valgrind, or for profiling tools such as oprofile.

sect1.para: When you start &app;, you will see a window that looks very much like the following:
The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands you need to use &app;.
The toolbar contains the basic debugging actions that can be used to run or step through the program being debugged.
When source files are open, this area will display source files of the program being debugged.
The Status notebook contains several tabs for displaying information about the program being debugged. These include the following:
Displays the current state of the call stack of the program being debugged.
Displays a list of all local variables and function arguments, in addition to their values and types.
If the program being debugged prints any output to the terminal, that output will be displayed in this tab.

This tab displays a list of all breakpoints that have been set. You can view the source code of a particular breakpoint by double-clicking an item in the list or by right-clicking and selecting Go to Source from the menu. In addition, breakpoints can be deleted, enabled, or disabled in this tab.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: This section explains how to start &app; and gives a basic overview of the application.

sect2.title: Starting &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

tip.title: Additional Command-line Options
tip.para: You can find a list of options that can be passed to &app; on the command line by typing &appcmd; --help-all.

sect3.title: Using the Workbench
sect3.para:
To select an executable program to debug, select
File
Execute...
, which should display the following dialog:

textobject.phrase: Shows dialog for selecting an executable to run

sect3.para: In this dialog, you can select the program to be debugged, any arguments or options to be passed to the executable on the command line, the working directory to run the executable in, and any Environment Variables that should be set when the executable is being debugged.

sect3.title: Using the Command Line
sect3.para: To start an executable program to debug from the command line, simply specify the name of the executable. You can either give an absolute path to the executable, or if it is in the path, you can simply give the basename of the executable. tip.title: Passing Options on the Command Line
tip.para: If you would like to pass command line options to the program that you are debugging, you should enclose them in quotes to prevent &app; from processing them: &appcmd; "prognam --arg1 --arg2".

sect3.title: Using the Workbench
sect3.para:
Select the menu item
File
Attach to Running Program...
, which should display the following dialog:

textobject.phrase: Shows dialog for attaching to a running program

sect3.para: Select a process from the list and click OK to start debugging the selected program. There may be a lot of processes listed in the dialog, so you can filter the list to only ones that that you are interested in by typing some text into the text entry located just below the list.

sect3.title: Using the Command Line
sect3.para: To attach to a running program from the command line, use the --attach option. The --attach option accepts either a pid or a process name. So, for example, to debug the running process foo which has a pid of 1121, you could either type &appcmd; --attach foo or &appcmd; --attach 1121.

sect3.title: Using the Workbench
sect3.para:
Select the menu item
File
Load Core File...
to bring up the following dialog, which will let you load a core file:

textobject.phrase: Shows dialog for loading a core file

sect3.title: Using the Command Line
sect3.para: Core files cannot be loaded from the command line.

sect2.title: Basic Debugging actions
sect2.para: step in, step out, step over, etc.

sect1.title: Debugging Sessions
sect1.para: &app; can save your debugging sessions for you so that you can resume them at a later time. This includes saving information such as which executable is being debugged, what environment variables are set, what command-line options are passed to the executable, which files are open, and which breakpoints are set so that you can get back to where you left off last time as quickly as possible.

sect2.title: Saving Sessions
sect2.para:
&app; will save your session automatically on exit, you don't even have to worry it. However, if you want to explicitly save the session before closing &app;, you can do so by selecting
File Save Session To Disk .

sect3.title: Using the Workbench
sect3.para:
Select
File Resume Saved Session...
and select a session from the list.

textobject.phrase: Shows dialog for resuming a saved session

sect3.title: From the Command Line
sect3.para: If you know the session ID of the session you want to run, you can start that debugging session from the command line. For example, if you want to run session number 3, you can do so with the following command: &appcmd; --executesession 3.

sect1.title: About &app;
sect1.para: &app; was written by Dodji Seketeli and Jonathon Jongsma, with contributions from many others. To find more information about &app;, please visit the &app; project website.
